questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question: Crowding out refers to a:

choices.A: fall in interest rates that reduces private investment.
choices.B: rise in private investment that reduces private consumption.
choices.C: rise in government borrowing that reduces the ability of the private sector to access investment funds.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. A fall in interest rates is likely to lead to a rise in investment. Crowding out refers to government borrowing that reduces the ability of the private sector to invest.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. A fall in interest rates is likely to lead to a rise in investment. Crowding out refers to government borrowing that reduces the ability of the private sector to invest.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question:
The government embarks on a policy intended to reduce the budget deficit. This is most likely:

  1. an expansionary fiscal policy.
  2. a contractionary fiscal policy.
  3. an example of quantitative easing.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Reducing the budget deficit would slow the economy, not expand it. Correct. A policy intended to reduce a budget deficit would involve raising taxes and/or reducing spending. Either action is fiscal and would likely cause the economy to slow, which is contractionary. Incorrect. Quantitative easing is an action of monetary policy and does not address the budget deficit, which is a fiscal issue. Fiscal Policy explain the implementation of fiscal policy and difficulties of implementation as well as whether a fiscal policy is expansionary or contractionary
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Reducing the budget deficit would slow the economy, not expand it.

  2. Correct. A policy intended to reduce a budget deficit would involve raising taxes and/or reducing spending. Either action is fiscal and would likely cause the economy to slow, which is contractionary.

  3. Incorrect. Quantitative easing is an action of monetary policy and does not address the budget deficit, which is a fiscal issue.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question:
If a government increases its spending on domestically produced goods by an amount that is financed by an equivalent increase in taxes, the aggregate demand will most likely:

  1. decrease.
  2. remain unchanged.
  3. increase.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $ c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c . This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect. Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $ c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c . This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect. Correct. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $ c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c . This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect. Fiscal Policy describe tools of fiscal policy, including their advantages and disadvantages
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.

  2. Incorrect. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.

  3. Correct. Aggregate demand rises when the government increases spending by the same amount as it raises taxes because the marginal propensity to spend out of disposable income is less than 1, and hence for every dollar less in disposable income, spending only falls by $c (where c is the marginal propensity to consume). Aggregate spending will fall less than the tax rise by a factor c. This additional output will, in turn, lead to further increases in income and output through the multiplier effect.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question: A contractionary fiscal policy will always involve which of the following?

choices.C: Fall in the budget deficit or rise in the surplus

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Note that a reduction in government spending could be accompanied by an even bigger fall in taxation, making it be expansionary.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Note that a reduction in government spending could be accompanied by an even bigger fall in taxation, making it be expansionary.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question: Which one of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.A: Ricardian equivalence refers to individuals having no idea of future tax liabilities.
choices.B: Governments do not allow political pressures to influence fiscal policies but do allow voters to affect monetary policies.
choices.C: If there is high unemployment in an economy, then easy monetary and fiscal policies should lead to an expansion in aggregate demand.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Note that governments often allow pressure groups to affect fiscal policy and that Ricardian equivalence involves individuals correctly anticipating future taxes. Thus, A and B are not correct choices.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Note that governments often allow pressure groups to affect fiscal policy and that Ricardian equivalence involves individuals correctly anticipating future taxes. Thus, A and B are not correct choices.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question:
The primary goal of both monetary and fiscal policy focuses on balancing economic growth and:

  1. inflation.
  2. employment.
  3. income distribution.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The goal of both monetary and fiscal policy is the creation of an economic environment characterized by positive, stable growth and low, stable inflation. Incorrect because the overarching goal of monetary and fiscal policy is to create economic conditions characterized by positive, stable economic growth and low, stable inflation. Achieving this goal promotes stability (rather than cyclicality) in employment, consumption, and saving/investment outcomes. Incorrect because the distribution of income (and wealth) lies within the purview of fiscal policy involving the government‚Äôs decisions concerning spending and taxes. By contrast, monetary policy refers to central bank activities directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. Income distribution is not a policy domain of monetary policy. Fiscal Policy compare monetary and fiscal policy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The goal of both monetary and fiscal policy is the creation of an economic environment characterized by positive, stable growth and low, stable inflation.

  2. Incorrect because the overarching goal of monetary and fiscal policy is to create economic conditions characterized by positive, stable economic growth and low, stable inflation. Achieving this goal promotes stability (rather than cyclicality) in employment, consumption, and saving/investment outcomes.

  3. Incorrect because the distribution of income (and wealth) lies within the purview of fiscal policy involving the government‚Äôs decisions concerning spending and taxes. By contrast, monetary policy refers to central bank activities directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy. Income distribution is not a policy domain of monetary policy.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question: Which statement regarding fiscal policy is most accurate?

choices.A: Cyclically adjusted budget deficits are appropriate indicators of fiscal policy.
choices.B: To raise business capital spending, personal income taxes should be reduced.
choices.C: An increase in the budget surplus is associated with expansionary fiscal policy.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Cyclically adjusted budget deficits are appropriate indicators of fiscal policy. These are defined as the deficit that would exist if the economy was at full employment (or full potential output).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Cyclically adjusted budget deficits are appropriate indicators of fiscal policy. These are defined as the deficit that would exist if the economy was at full employment (or full potential output).

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question: The least likely explanation for why fiscal policy cannot stabilize aggregate demand completely is that:

choices.A: private sector behavior changes over time.
choices.B: policy changes are implemented very quickly.
choices.C: fiscal policy focuses more on inflation than on unemployment.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Fiscal policy is subject to recognition, action, and impact lags.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Fiscal policy is subject to recognition, action, and impact lags.

questions.title: Fiscal Policy
questions.question:
Which of the following is most likely an objective of fiscal policy?

  1. Maintaining price stability
  2. Affecting aggregate demand
  3. Achieving an exchange rate target
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because ensuring price stability is an objective of monetary policy not fiscal policy. There is one overarching objective [of the central bank] that most seem to acknowledge explicitly, and that is the objective of maintaining price stability. Correct because the tools associated with fiscal policy involve the use of government spending and changing tax revenue to affect a number of aspects of the economy: including the overall level of aggregate demand in an economy and hence the level of economic activity. Incorrect because targeting exchange rates is a part of monetary not fiscal policy. Many developing economies choose to operate monetary policy by targeting their currency‚Äôs exchange rate, rather than an explicit level of domestic inflation. Fiscal Policy describe roles and objectives of fiscal policy as well as arguments as to whether the size of a national debt relative to GDP matters
